content.question:
A researcher’s hypothesis is that the average length of salmon returning to spawn from an Alaskan river is less than the historical average length of 24 inches. The researcher collects a random sample of 45 salmon, measures the length of each fish, and computes an average length of 22 inches, with a standard deviation of 3.1 inches.
Which of the following is the appropriate test for the researcher’s hypothesis?

choices.label: A matched-pairs <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-test for a mean difference
A two-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-test for a difference between means
A one-sample <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-test for a population mean
A one-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-test for a population mean
A one-sample <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-test for a population proportion

content.answer: A one-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-test for a population mean

topic.text: 7.4: Setting Up a Test for a Population Mean

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Identify an appropriate inference method for significance tests.
